qas.question: What may have a wide range of meanings?
What have been beneficial in the reconstruction of Middle Chinese?

context: <a0_0>Modern Chinese<a0_0/> has many homophones; thus the same spoken syllable may be represented by many characters, depending on meaning. A <a1_0>single character<a1_0/> may also have a range of meanings, or sometimes quite distinct meanings; occasionally these correspond to different pronunciations. Cognates in the several varieties of Chinese are generally written with the same character. They typically have similar meanings, but often quite different pronunciations. In other languages, most significantly today in Japanese and sometimes in Korean, characters are used to represent Chinese loanwords, to represent native words independent of the Chinese pronunciation, and as purely phonetic elements based on their pronunciation in the historical variety of Chinese from which they were acquired. These foreign adaptations of Chinese pronunciation are known as <a2_0>Sino-Xenic pronunciations<a2_0/>, and have been useful in the reconstruction of Middle Chinese.
